column1: 0145|1:45|In the end I accepted a glass of claret. It seemed both churlish and censorious to let him drink alone. The carriage-clock stuck 1:45 before he roused himself and said: "Sorry
column2: Cousin. Rather drunk. Be glad of your shoulder. To bed

column1: 0145|fifteen minutes to two|When it was ten or fifteen minutes to two the deacon would come in; he was a lanky young man of twenty-two
column3: with no beard and hardly a perceptible mustache. Going into the drawing room
column4: he crossed himself before the ikon
column6:
and held out his hand to Von Koren.
"Good morning
column7: the zoologist said coldly. Where have you been?"

column1: 0145|1:45 A.M.|Kaplan looked even more like hell than usual. The skin across the tops of his cheeks and around his eyes was blistered from frostbite. His limping indicated that he'd probably frostbitten some toes as well. The last communication from him the night before had been at 1:45 A.M.
column2: when he radioed to let the department know he was finally giving up.
